bibl.title: Report from Valery Havard to the Adjutant General, August 12, 1901

div1.p: Havard reports on the claims of Caldas and Bellingaghi that they discovered a preventative and curative serum for yellow fever. Havard is skeptical because Caldas does not provide any information regarding his process of isolation and culture. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Report from Valery Havard to the Adjutant General, August 12, 1901
div1.opener:
File under Caldas & Bellingaghi
L.S. 221. S.
HEADQUARTERS
DEPARTMENT OF CUBA
OFFICE OF CHIEF SURGEON,
HAVANA.
August 12th., 1901.
The Adjutant General,
Department of Cuba,
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report that the medical commission
detailed by Circular Letter No. 59 Headquarters Department of
Cuba, 1901, met at four o'clock p.m. August 5, 1901, at Las Animas
Hospital, and proceeded to examine into the alleged discoveries,
propositions and claims of Drs. Caldas and Bellinzaghi. These
gentlemen, being both present, submitted papers and testimonials
establishing their professional standing as physicians and
bacteriologists. Dr. Caldas then stated that he had discovered
the causative microbe of yellow fever and prepared therefrom
preventive and curative serums. For special reasons, Dr. Caldas
is not willing at this time to exhibit his microbe and dis-
close his process of isolation and culture, but desires to
demonstrate the efficacy of his preventive serum, and in that
indirect way prove that his microbe is really the cause of
yellow fever. These gentlemen then submitted the following
proposition to the board: That they be allowed to inoculate
a certain number of volunteer non-immunes with their preven-
tive serum, and then that these non-immunes be infected with
the yellow fever germ, either by mosquitoe bites or direct
blood injections. They contend that all non-immunes thus
inoculated, or vaccinated, cannot contract yellow fever and will
remain completely immunized for at least several years.

After careful consideration of the subject the board care
2
to the conclusion that, on account of the refusal of Dr Caldas
to demonstrate his microbe, and thus put his claim upon an
entirely scientific basis, it is unable to recommend an active
participation and cooperation in the testing of Dr Caldas'
preventive serum. The board however sees no objection to fur
-nish him and his colleague the opportunity and every reason-
able facility to carry on their experiments, to supervise them
and then officially report upon them. For this purpose, the
board respectfully recommends that a sum, not to exceed $400.,
be authorized to be expended if, in its opinion, the interest
of science and of this island appear to justify such expendi-
ture.
